ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ASSISTANCE FOR THE UNEMPLOYED


    1. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Acting Minister for Manpower, with the unemployment rate forecast to creep up and perhaps even surpass the levels experienced in the 1998 downturn, will his Ministry consider further interim measures to help the unemployed, at least for a period, subject to suitable means

Column: 2259

testing, until they are able to become financially independent again.

    2. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Acting Minister for Manpower in view of the current unemployment situation and projected pessimistic employment forecast, whether he will introduce additional financial assistance schemes to help those who are unemployed and who face financial difficulties.

    3. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Acting Minister for Manpower (a) whether he is aware that, despite the Utilities Save scheme introduced in the Budget, there is a substantial number of households who are unable to pay utility bills and have had their supplies disconnected; and (b) whether he will introduce measures or provide specific assistance schemes to help these households.

    The Acting Minister for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I would like to take Question Nos. 1 to 3 together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Because the Questions have been asked from various agencies, this reply is with the inputs from the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Community Development and Sports, Ministry of the Environment and Ministry of Trade and Industry.

    As the Member rightly pointed out, since 1998, as economic conditions worsened, the Government appreciated that more would face hardship. In response, several measures have been introduced to help lower income groups and unemployed workers cope with the difficult times. These measures involved not just temporary financial assistance, but also job matching and placement services, and specific schemes and programmes to facilitate re-entry into the workforce.

    On financial assistance, the Government works closely with Community Development Councils (CDCs) and voluntary welfare organisations (VWOs) to tailor

Column: 2260

the assistance to households in need. For instance, the unemployed who have a low household income can apply for interim financial assistance at their Community Development Councils. Short-term financial aid will be granted for six months, subject to a review every three months. In FY2002, 6,700 unemployed Singaporeans were helped by this scheme. 88% of them managed to get a job within three months and become financially independent.

    In addition, families who live in 1-, 2- or 3-room rental and purchased flats who have difficulty paying their rental, utilities or conservancy charges can obtain short-term relief to tide over temporary crises. They may apply for monthly subsidies for rent, utilities and service and conservancy charges, up to a maximum monthly cap of $90 for utilities and $35 for service and conservancy charges. For those lower income families that are unable to pay their utility bills - this is in reply to Mr Low Thia Khiang - PUB has already adopted the practice of thimbling their water supply instead of cutting it off completely since late 2002. This has enabled them to continue to have access to a minimum supply of water for basic needs. PUB will extend this practice until the economic situation improves.

    As for facilitating job placement, between December 2001 and last month, 152,000 visits for job assistance under MOM's Career Link and its Distributed Career Link Network were recorded; of these, 19,600 people were placed into jobs. Recently, we have seen an increase in take-up rate and this is encouraging. MOM also introduced a number of industry-targeted programmes to place and train or convert job seekers for jobs in growth or strategic sectors. More than 1,200 Singaporeans have benefited from such programmes so far. Further, training programmes are in place to ensure that workers' skill sets develop in tandem with the economy. About 80,000 workers have benefited from the Skills Redevelopment Programme.

    I share Members' concern on the impact of a further rise in overall unemployment rate, as pointed out by Dr Amy Khor.

Column: 2261

Hence, MOM is working towards introducing more place and train programmes in other sub-sectors which offer employment opportunities. We will support retooling and upskilling workers and later I will be introducing a Bill which will enable us to start the CET statutory board. These developments will enable MOM and its partners to be more effective in helping the unemployed find jobs.

    The various financial, training and employment assistance measures which I have just described provide a sound and holistic framework for helping unemployed and low-income Singaporeans in this downturn. We will have to calibrate the extent of assistance depending on economic circumstances, and feedback from MPs, VWOs, and officers on the ground.

    Unfortunately, our experience shows that despite the difficult conditions, there are jobs which companies still cannot find Singaporeans to fill. Hence, the Government will need to tighten the connection between financial assistance and efforts on the part of individuals to look for jobs, take up jobs that are available and undergo training. We will monitor closely how well the existing schemes are working and, wherever necessary, to streamline and improve the assistance framework to make it more effective.

    Ultimately, jobs and self-reliance are the best guarantee of financial independence, self-confidence and personal dignity. I urge Singaporeans who are out of work to be flexible and realistic in their search for jobs. They should not turn down job opportunities which may not be ideal, but which can financially tide them over this downturn.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister specifically about the white collar workers. It has been reported that about half of the currently unemployed are white collar workers. Are there any specific measures in place or being planned to help this specific group of workers, especially they are reporting

Column: 2262

that they are encountering resistance from prospective employers due to cynicism about their over-qualification and possible change of job when the economy turns around?

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Sir, saying that half of the workers unemployed are white collar workers does not quite lend equanimity to the situation. Let me give a clearer picture.

    Of all the unemployed residents - if we take the overall global number of those who are unemployed - the unemployment rate for degree holders is 3.8%, in other words, 96% of those with degrees are employed. For diploma holders, it is 3.5%; upper secondary, 3.4%. Nonetheless, we do agree with Dr Amy Khor that more needs to be done to help every sector of the unemployed and our programmes are crafted not so much at either blue or white collar workers but industry-specific, to look at areas where there is growth and to enable workers who have been unemployed or retrenched from one sector to convert to another sector.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister how he would facilitate the employment of young graduates who are today finding themselves very disillusioned when they graduate from the university, especially when they are losing out to the diploma holders as well as the ITE graduates.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Sir, I think the Member has touched on the issue of job vacancies. Let me give some numbers again.

    As of March 2003, there were still about 12,000 job vacancies in the private sector. There are still about 31% or 4,000 jobs for professionals, managers, executives and technical vocations. Also, in the public sector, there are about 1,800 jobs available for professionals and associate professionals. It is not only a question of the grade of jobs but also the industry. Yes, there is disruptive unemployment, in other words, particular sectors have shrunk so that those who work in one sector cannot go back to that sector and they have to convert to another sector. We have created specific schemes targeted

Column: 2263

at this group. One particular scheme is called the Strategic Manpower Conversion Programme and it is aimed especially at professionals to help them change. For example, an executive who is retrenched from the electronics sector can switch to the healthcare sector. There are these schemes available. We also work with professional organisations, such as SHRI and SPEC, to help them help professionals to make this conversion.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): I would like to ask the Minister whether he deems the current assistance schemes for the unemployed sufficient and able to help them.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Sir, the Member fully appreciates that the word "sufficient" is subjective. Let me give some objectivity to his question in terms of those who are in utility account arrears, which he has mentioned. Yes, for everyone who suffers hardship, we empathise, but we need to be mindful of the numbers. The percentage of households who have arrears on utilities is 1% of all accounts. Even in the 1-room and 2-room HDB flats, it is around 5%.

    The Energy Market Authority has set for itself particular targets to try to bring down the number of accounts in arrears to reduce the figure to pre-1999 level, which is 0.2% eventually. So that is the working target internally.

    As I have also mentioned, PUB, instead of disconnecting supply, has agreed that they will use thimbling so that their essential water requirements are still met. We will work hard and, as I said, we will calibrate the financial assistance schemes with our CDCs and VWOs to respond to those in need. But the number suggests that there is a declining trend of those who are in arrears.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, while we are asking the workers to change their mindset to accept other jobs, has the Ministry any plan to also work at changing the mindset of some employers who are against employing older workers who

Column: 2264

would otherwise be more than qualified for the job?

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Sir, we actively do this, but to really get the effect, my Ministry has decided that a holistic approach is better, which means that not only we work on the mindset of all those parties involved but we also introduce enabling schemes. One particular enabling scheme, as I have mentioned previously in this House, is the People-for-Jobs Traineeship Programme where Government will fund half of the worker's salary for about six months or $2,000, whichever is less. This will facilitate, if you like, the employer to accept the employee and for Government to show its support and for that six months for the employee to be tested in the new job. I am sure that those who have signed up for this scheme will prove their own worth in due time.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister how successful has this People-for-Jobs Traineeship Programme been.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Sir, I do not have the exact number but, from my recall, about 4,000-odd people have been placed on this scheme since it was introduced. But I would have to check the number.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the Minister said that the Ministry would calibrate the assistance schemes. I would like to ask him whether or not the Government has calibrated the latest employment situation and the financial assistance schemes and whether he is satisfied that the current financial assistance schemes - despite the number that he has mentioned about the arrears position in utilities - such as the Rents and Utilities Assistance Scheme as well as other interim financial assistance schemes, are actually helpful and sufficient to take care of the unemployed.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Before I answer Mr Low Thia Khiang, my other more learned colleague has told me that actually 10,000 people took up the People-for-Jobs Traineeship Programme, of which 4,000 stayed on. I will again have to check on the numbers.

Column: 2265



    Is it sufficient? It is a relative word. I would rather give the Member numbers so that we know where we are now and in the future. As I said, the number of accounts in utility arrears is 1%. The average amount of arrears for each account is about $1,000 and the trend is down.

    Are we satisfied? Can anyone be satisfied? We will work with our CDCs and VWOs and we will monitor the situation and calibrate the assistance in tandem with the hardship felt on the ground and in tandem with the economic conditions.

Column: 2265

WAGE RESTRUCTURING


    4. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Acting Minister for Manpower in view of National Wage Council's recommendation for wage restructuring and the global competition that our companies are faced with, (a) will his Ministry facilitate the review of wages in both the local and global industries and provide a database of such reviews for companies to make informed decisions timely; and (b) how can his Ministry be better poised to partner industry players to carry out job profiling exercises which are essential in supporting wage restructuring and minimising tensions between employers and unions during restructuring exercises.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Member rightly pointed out, in the face of stiff global competition, the NWC has, in its wage guidelines for July 2003 and June 2004, urged companies and unions to speed up wage restructuring to enhance wage flexibility and competitiveness. It has also recommended that a Tripartite Taskforce be set up to drive this process of wage restructuring.

    The Government has accepted these recommendations and a Tripartite Taskforce has been set up to help companies in their wage reform. This Taskforce is chaired by my Permanent Secretary and will also include representatives from the unions and employers.

Column: 2266



    I thank the Member for her inputs and agree that more information regarding wage reviews should be provided periodically to industries. We have recognised that this is a deficiency and we will work towards that. In other words, we will provide market information more readily to companies to see what the hiring salaries are. We will take her inputs into account.

    The Taskforce will provide companies with relevant information and analysis on wage cost, formulate flexible and competitive wage models, and highlight the experiences of companies in their wage reform. The Taskforce will also recommend measures and options that companies and unions can adopt in restructuring their wage system.

    Together with the tripartite partners, my Ministry will work closely with industries, companies, unions and professional societies to implement changes to their wage systems and look into skills upgrading and industry transformation that would complement wage reform. The successful implementation of wage reform and the upgrading of our workers' capabilities will help enhance the competitiveness and employability of our workforce.

    The Taskforce is expected to release its final report within six months.

Column: 2266

ADOPTION OF ALTERNATIVES TO RETRENCHMENT


    5. Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Acting Minister for Manpower what steps his Ministry has in place to (i) ensure that employers use retrenchments as a last resort to save costs and (ii) encourage employers to use other strategies such as job-sharing, part-time work or cutting back on frills such as company cars as cost-saving measures.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Sir, MOM has been providing retrenchment advisory services to help companies explore feasible alternatives to retrenchment, as Ms Braema Mathi has suggested. We have asked

Column: 2267

them to carry out retrenchment only as a last resort.

    Following the recommendations of the Tripartite Panel on Retrenchments in June 1998, a special Retrenchment Advisory Unit under the Labour Relations Department of the Ministry was set up. This Unit monitors retrenchment trend, advises companies on how retrenchments can be carried out smoothly and fairly to the extent possible, provides conciliatory assistance to resolve disputes, disseminates information relating to retrenchment through brochures and leaflets. The Unit also manages a Retrenchment Assistance Hotline to enable employers facing excess manpower to seek timely advice and assistance on retrenchment issues. Companies are urged to retrench workers as a last resort and are advised to consider the following alternatives if they have excess manpower.

    One, take the opportunity to train and upgrade their workers' skills under the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP), which is exactly what we did in terms of our assistance schemes during the SARS crisis for tourism and hospitality-related sectors. The Government issued a $57 million budget for training and for some sectors, as you might have read, the uptake was significant and did allay further retrenchments.

    Two, look for alternative areas of work within the company to deploy the surplus workers, including implementing job-sharing and part-time work, as well as other cost-cutting measures.

    Three, implement shorter work week or temporary lay-offs.

    Four, if it has a flexible wage system in place, use it to adjust its wage cost.

    To help promote the adoption of the above-mentioned alternatives to retrenchment, the Ministry proactively visited companies with excess manpower. In other words, we do not wait for them to call us. We monitor the trends and then we go down to the ground and try to manage it. Between March and October

Column: 2268

2002, MOM visited 110 companies ranging from SMEs to large firms employing over 500 staff.

    With the implementation of the various alternatives to retrenchments, many jobs have been saved as companies could avoid retrenchments and where retrenchment is unavoidable, the number of workers affected could be minimised.

Column: 2268

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND
(Liberalisation on use)


    6. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Acting Minister for Manpower will the Government consider liberalising the use of Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies for purposes of (i) supporting overseas education of children who are not able to gain admission into local universities so long as any housing loan owing has been paid up by the CPF account holder; and (ii) subsidising the start-up of a small business (up to a comfortable limit as determined by CPF) as part of the Government's encouragement for self-employment by the unemployed.

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Mr Speaker, Sir, the primary objective of the CPF is to help members save for their retirement, healthcare and housing needs. While often stated in these simple terms and often repeated, we should be reminded again that our CPF system remains a cornerstone on which we build our social and indeed economic well-being. We should resist strenuously attempts to adulterate the original aims and intents of the CPF system. Yes, from time to time, we may have to recalibrate the amount we put aside to meet these basic needs because there is a trade-off from too high a statutory burden for wages. We risk becoming less competitive and thereby restrict employment creation, we create less jobs. In other words, we should make sure that the majority of the population has enough to cover these basic needs and we should neither under or over-provide.

    The CPF Education Scheme was introduced in 1989 as a special concession to

Column: 2269

help lower-income families support themselves or their children through full-time local tertiary education. To allow CPF savings for overseas tertiary education would be a further deviation from the aims of the CPF scheme. It would also introduce opportunities for over-consumption. For example, an overseas engineering course could cost as much as $58,000 a year as compared to $5,650 at the NUS for the academic year 2003/2004.

    Further, if we did allow it, this availability of the use of CPF savings would put unwelcome pressure on parents to fund an ever-increasing aspiration of children to pursue a tertiary education. I am not for it. I would rather we hold the line than ask parents to do it. There are other avenues of scholarships and loan schemes available to good students who would benefit from an university education, anywhere.

    It is for this same reason of remaining pure to the original and focused aims of the CPF scheme that I am against allowing the early withdrawal of CPF savings for business start-ups. There is no certainty that all start-ups will thrive and indeed data proves the contrary, that the majority of start-ups fizzles out. We run the risk of many members losing their retirement savings for a few to make good.

    For those intending to start their own businesses, they could look to the Government or private incentives and financing schemes for assistance. The Micro Loan Programme, for example, administered by SPRING Singapore and offered through participating financial institutions, is a fixed interest rate financing programme designed to help the very small local enterprises gain better access to financing.
